content.description:
The left route on the right set of chains.  This is the easiest lead on

The Appendage

.  Straight forward climbing, but, you know, too short.
content.protection: 4 bolts on the way to the anchors.

content.description:
An agreeable jaunt up the west side of

The Appendage

on the short faces between several narrow ledges.

This line is good for beginning leaders; the three bolts protect the harder bits well and the climbing is straightforward but rewarding.
content.protection: 3 bolts, chain anchors. The chains are reachable via an easy scramble to the left.
content.location:
The left-most, bolted line on

The Appendage

proper; starts just east of the trees that are west of the formation.

(There is another 3-bolt route (

Butterface

) which is a bit uphill on the next slabby faceÂ—it should be obvious that it is harder than 5.4.)

content.description: The furthest left route.  This route climbs to the chains clipping the last bolt of The Edge.  There is a small roof pull.  Some of the flakes are loose so be careful.  Too short and inconsistent a route for more than 1 star.

A short, juggy route up a slightly overhanging arete. Getting to and clipping the second bolt is probably the crux.

The rock is mostly solid up through the bolts and then broken and chossy past the last bolt to the anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts to rap anchors. The anchors are quite a ways above the last bolt over some low-angled, chossy rock. Top-roping this is doable but will abrade your rope. Consider extending the anchor with some static rope.
content.location:
This is the right-most bolted route at

The Appendage

.

content.description:
This is the right line on the left set of anchors.  Fun jams and good positions will get you to the present first bolt, which will clip with some muscle.  Swing out onto the west face and clip the last bolt and head for the chains.

Again, too short for more than 1 star but better than

Lead

.

Nice jaunt up the double crack system starting just right of "The Bulge" and veering right, halfway up, toward the chains for "Full Appendage". The left crack starts at hands and widens to off-width before the roof while the right side stays more consistent at small fingers. The two cracks are less than 2 feet apart so can easily use both.

A fun 5.8 variation is at the top if you decide to say left at the roof and jam/lieback the fist crack. Once over the roof, just traverse right about 8 feet to meet up with the original route at the nearest chains above "Full Appendage".

The route can be done as a chimney, as a proper jam-fest, as more of a face climb, or a combo of all three. Take your pick!
content.protection:
Anything from brass offsets to a #5 Camalot, seriously just pick an assortment of about 4 or 5 pieces, and it'll probably work. (Save a #3 for the end if you do the 5.8 roof variation)

A couple extendable draws are nice, especially if placing pro in both cracks, or if placing anything in the 5.8 roof finish and traversing.
content.location: Hop in the chimney directly right of "The Bulge"

content.description: A short crack, loose and crumbly at the bottom, with six feet of really nice tight hands/off-fingers at the top.
content.protection: A few cams from .5 to 3 inches. Hangers-and-chain anchors.
content.location:
About ten feet left of

Butterface

on the same face. Uphill (north) and in the gully to the west of the main

Appendage

climbs.

content.description: Delicate face climbing with interesting finger locks and crimps.
content.location:
The orange-colored face 25 feet left of

The Ledge

.

content.description: The right line on the right set of anchors.  6 bolts that will pull at your tendons.  Very fun route, very pumpy.  Length wasn't too bad, but what hurt this route is that you can use the right wall, in fact, it is a pain in the a$$ to not use that right wall, but that right wall hurts (lessens) the climb.  The finish is also weird, with a very painful (sliced into my finger, painful) crack hold at the 6th bolt.
content.protection: 6 bolts on the way to the chains.
